sanskrit:
बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम् ।
मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकरः ॥३५॥
transliteration:
bṛhat-sāma tathā sāmnāṁ gāyatrī chandasām aham |
māsānāṁ mārga-śīrṣo'ham ṛtūnāṁ kusumākaraḥ ||35||
translation: Of the Sama Veda hymns, I am the Brihat-sama; of meters, I am the Gayatri; of months, I am Margashirsha (November-December); and of seasons, I am the spring, which brings forth flowers.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna continues His enumeration of divine manifestations by identifying Himself with the most excellent representatives of various categories. The Brihat-sama is considered the most important of the Sama Veda hymns, used in elaborate Vedic rituals and known for its melodious chanting. The Gayatri meter, consisting of twenty-four syllables arranged in three lines of eight syllables each, is revered as the most sacred of all Vedic meters and is the foundation of the famous Gayatri mantra. These represent the pinnacle of Vedic knowledge and spiritual practice.

Margashirsha (also known as Agrahayana), corresponding to November-December, is considered the most pleasant month in the Indian calendar, marking the beginning of the harvest season with moderate temperatures and clear skies. Spring (Kusumakara, literally 'flower-maker') is universally beloved as the season of renewal, beauty, and abundance when nature displays its full glory. Through these examples, Krishna demonstrates that He is present in whatever is most beautiful, auspicious, and conducive to spiritual contemplation in the natural world.

This verse illustrates the pedagogical method of the Vibhuti Yoga chapter, where Krishna systematically reveals His presence in the most excellent manifestations across different domains of existence. By recognizing the divine in these supreme expressions of beauty and excellence, the devotee learns to see God everywhere and develops a contemplative awareness that transforms ordinary perception into spiritual vision. This practice helps bridge the gap between the formless Absolute and the manifest world of forms.
speaker: Krishna
